description: A mesmerizing 8-meter-high kinetic sculpture of two transparent steel figures that move slowly to pass through each other and become one, repeating this poetic dance every 10 minutes. Created by renowned Georgian artist Tamara Kvesitadze in 2010, it symbolizes eternal love, cultural unity, and the tragic romance between an Azerbaijani Muslim and a Georgian princess.

Figures move continuously, merging and separating every 10 minutes

Represents the merging of different cultures and religions

vibe: Romantic, contemplative, and deeply emotional. The slow, deliberate movement creates a meditative atmosphere that draws crowds into silent observation. Many couples visit to witness this symbol of eternal love, while others are moved by the cultural symbolism and tragic backstory. The atmosphere is reverent yet accessible.

Beautiful artistic piece perfect for photography

unique_facts: Inspired by Kurban Said's 1937 worldwide bestseller 'Ali and Nino'
Often called the 'Caucasian Romeo and Juliet' - a tragic cross-cultural love story
Ali Shirvanshir was an Azerbaijani aristocrat, Nino Kipiani was a Georgian princess's daughter
Ali (Muslim) and Nino (Christian) finally unite but Ali is killed in war
Tamara Kvesitadze was born in 1968 and is especially known for kinetic sculptures
The sculpture was designed in 2007 and installed in 2010
Made its international debut at Venice Biennale before coming to Batumi
The movement symbolizes both the unity and inevitable separations in relationships
Represents the merging of Azerbaijani and Georgian cultures
The figures are almost translucent, creating different visual effects based on lighting
surprises: The sculpture moves much slower than videos suggest - it's hypnotically gradual
Many visitors unknowingly watch for the full 10-minute cycle, transfixed by the motion
The emotional response is universal, transcending language and cultural barriers
Despite being modern (2010), it has become Batumi's most iconic symbol
The engineering allows for continuous 24/7 operation without visible mechanical parts
Locals and tourists alike gather every evening to watch, creating a shared ritual
The tragic real story behind the sculpture adds layers of meaning most don't expect
Originally had a different official name ('Man and Woman') but everyone calls it Ali and Nino
The sculpture has become a pilgrimage site for couples and hopeless romantics
Weather and time of day dramatically change how the transparent steel appears
